why is this changed from error to info?
can we move this enabling LG2 in pldmtool into a different commit altogether?
if enabling part is separate for pldmtool then lg2 logs from pldmtool will be creating error so enabling part can't go for different commit.
@kamal I didn't get you, Could you move the enabling as well as lg2 logs in pldmtool as a separate commit?

'e' returns Exception class object and e.what() returns a string, so i am printing exception string in error logs.
please let me know if you have something else in mind to explain.

> 'e' returns Exception class object and e.what() returns a string, so i am printing exception string in error logs.
> please let me know if you have something else in mind to explain.

What I mean is that lg2 supports e, and the result output by it is the same as e.what()

If result output is same for both then i would recommend to keep e.what() for better readability. if any major difference is there then i can make change in all the files. please let me know your opinion.

How is being less succinct improving readability? I agree with George, please just pass `e`and let the lg2 APIs do the work. The approach also gives the lg2 implementation the option of changing what it does with the exception in the future.

> How is being less succinct improving readability? I agree with George, please just pass `e`and let the lg2 APIs do the work. The approach also gives the lg2 implementation the option of changing what it does with the exception in the future.

+1
Changes are done as mentioned above.

Hello, I've commented on a problematic pattern I keep seeing people implement in logging patches. It has to stop at some point, and you're the unlucky person to field my gripe.

Please address the concern throughout the entire patch.

So `ERROR=` wasn't in the format string previously. Why are we adding this? The message strings are supposed to be for human consumption, and this isn't super friendly. Instead we can use:

```
"Invalid PLDM package header: {ERR_EXCEP}", "ERR_EXCEP", e);
```

This will render as something like the following where I've invented an exception description:

```
"Invalid PLDM package header: Value too large for defined data type
```

This is quite legible to humans.

A core behaviour of `lg2` is that it exploit's the [journal's structured logging](https://0pointer.de/blog/projects/journal-submit.html). All the variables interpolated into the message string are logged to the journal as separate key/value pairs in the journal entry. To make that concrete, here's an example entry from `phosphor-time-manager`, which uses `lg2`:

```
# journalctl --identifier=phosphor-time-manager --boot
Sep 23 06:09:57 cc-nvme-mi phosphor-time-manager[373]: Time mode has been changed to xyz.openbmc_project.Time.Synchronization.Method.NTP
Sep 23 06:09:58 cc-nvme-mi phosphor-time-manager[373]: Updated NTP setting: True
```

We can see here that e.g. the time manager has logged that it's changing modes to NTP. But we can get more metadata about that specific message by exposing the variables captured in the structured logging:

```
# journalctl --identifier=phosphor-time-manager --boot --output=verbose | grep -v '    _' | head -n 9
Sat 2023-09-23 06:09:57.645208 UTC [s=85c1cb5f8e02445aa110a5164c9c07f6;i=244;b=ffd111d3cdca41c8893bb728a1c6cb20;m=133a5a0;t=606009314d0d9;x=9a54e8714754a6cb]
    PRIORITY=6
    MESSAGE=Time mode has been changed to xyz.openbmc_project.Time.Synchronization.Method.NTP
    LOG2_FMTMSG=Time mode has been changed to {MODE}
    CODE_FILE=/usr/src/debug/phosphor-time-manager/1.0+git/manager.cpp
    CODE_LINE=98
    CODE_FUNC=bool phosphor::time::Manager::setCurrentTimeMode(const std::string&)
    MODE=xyz.openbmc_project.Time.Synchronization.Method.NTP
    SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=phosphor-time-manager
```

Specifically, we find the key/value entry `MODE=xyz.openbmc_project.Time.Synchronization.Method.NTP` is captured, independent of the `MESSAGE` line. Further, we also see that `LOG2_FMTMSG=Time mode has been changed to {MODE}` is captured, which tells us how the `MESSAGE` entry was generated from the structured data.

There's no need to add `ERROR=` into the message string. It doesn't help human readability, and the structured logging key/value pairs provide a much more reliable method for extracting the metadata than trying to parse `MESSAGE`.

Please remove this pattern throughout the patch. Try to find a way to write the message strings so they are easily consumed by humans as is their intent.
I'd prefer if errors were consistently ERROR.
I've pushed [anti-patterns: Ill-defined data structuring in `lg2` message strings](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/68923) to capture my feelings above.

Hi @andrew,
Thanks for the lg2 explanation. 
As per your suggestion, I have modified ERROR pattern throughout the patch.
I have modified as per andrew's suggestion.
I think you've missed the crux of my comment if you've just removed the string "ERROR=" from your patch.

Hi Kamalkumar, unfortunately I feel you haven't completely grasped the crux of my comment on PS9. It didn't just apply to the string `ERROR=` in your log messages. Perhaps it's best to have a conversation on discord so we can pick apart the misunderstandings without the latency of gerrit comments?

But what about `PATH=`? What about `TIME INTERFACE=`?

If someone else logged a message like this, is it something you would find comfortable reading in the logs?

What goes in the message string is a choice. It's not the case that if the data isn't in the message string it isn't captured. Any parameters provided to the lg2 logging call will be captured in the structured log data, regardless of whether the value is interpolated into the message or not.

As I mentioned in the previous comment you can access `ERR_EXCEP`, `BMC_TIME_PATH` and `TIME_INTF` using `journalctl --output=verbose`.

Please make this log message something that is comfortably read by humans. Do not create ad-hoc, ill-defined structured data _inside_ the human-centric log message. Leave that to the structured logging entry created by the journal.

Please audit the rest of your log entries to address the concern.
got you andrew, I have made changes as per suggestion, please check.

For consistency please use ERROR.

I'm not sure what Andrew feels about this, but I would expect something more like: "Invalid PLDM package header: {ERROR}".

Consider this feedback throughout.

My suggestion:

"Error getting time from Elapsed property at {PATH} on {INTERFACE}: {ERROR}".
This is frankly stupid code but you can fix that in another commit.
will take care with another improvement commit.

My suggestion: 

"Error constructing table entry for {ATTR}: {ERROR}"
It kind of looks to me like there is useful information missing here related to the dbus operation, right?  Please also incorporate feedback given elsewhere.
Changes done as suggested and added interface info.
Why are we casting?  If this is an enum use `to_underlying`.
state is uint8_t type, so removed casting since lg2 support uint8 type.
Can you clean this one up?

I know you didn't write this, but this is a lot of words.  Maybe we could be more succinct.

"ERROR".

I'm not sure why this is called "file handle".  It looks like it is just a string.  Is it a path?

Suggest something like: "Handle ({HANDLE}) does not exist in the file table: {ERROR}".

I don't like the first value of the message being a variable.
nit: You didn't add the colon (:).
Again, not your fault, but kind of sad how we have 100s of lines of nearly duplicated code.
Also a bit sad that we're catching `InternalFailure`, which was meant to indicate something unrecoverable, and that we're assuming that it means `PLDM_INVALID_FILE_TYPE` here.
please suggest alternative, so will do as part of different commit.

Hi Kamalkumar, broadly this is much better than when I last reviewed. Thanks for taking on the feedback and incorporating it into the patch. I have some further comments. Some are a bit nitpicky, but from experience they should reduce some stress when reading logs while tracking down a bug.
If we're trying to find something and we fail, it's very useful to log what it is we're trying to find, given that failing is the exceptional case.
Nit: Why did you change the capitalisation of 'n' here? My preferences is that log messages are capitalised in the same manner as a sentence.

here we are finding new state of property and we are not aware about what state.
if you give suggestion will resolve as part of new commit.

Nit: I think this is better phrased as `Error getting integer attribute '{ATTR}' from '{INTERFACE}': {ERROR}".

Two things here:

1. Swap `{ATTR} attribute` to `attribute {ATTR}`
2. Put single-quotes around the interpolations. This helps in the case that they're somehow the empty string

Point 2 applies generally to interpolating any string. However, it's not necessary to put quotes around values that aren't strings. For instance, there's no need to add quotes around `{ERROR}` because it's value is not a string type.

Please address both these points throughout the patch.
Must we pass the C string here? I forget.

See previous comment:

`"Error getting string attribute '{ATTR}' from '{INTERFACE}': {ERROR}"`
The first letter of the log message should be capitalised, just like a regular sentence. The original message had this correct. Please audit your patch and fix this issue throughout.
Hi Kamalkumar, thanks again. This looks good to me now.
